message_1: A drug manufacturer claims that the mean lifespan of their pill is 60 days with a standard deviation of 3 days. A sample of 25 pills is randomly selected. What is the probability that the sample mean lifespan is greater than 62 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the z-score formula for sample means:

z = (X̄ - μ) / (σ / √n)

where X̄ is the sample mean, μ is the population mean, σ is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size.

In this case, we have:
μ = 60 days (the mean lifespan of the pill)
σ = 3 days (the standard deviation of the pill's lifespan)
n = 25 (the sample size)
X̄ = 62 days (the sample mean we want to find the probability for)

Now, we can plug these values into the z-score formula:

z = (62 - 60) / (3 / √25)
z = 2 / (3 / 5)
z = 2 / 0.6
z ≈ 3.33

Now that we have the z-score, we can use a standard normal distribution table (also known as a z-table) to find the probability that the sample mean lifespan is greater than 62 days. 

Looking up a z-score of 3.33 in a z-table, we find that the area to the left of this z-score is approximately 0.9996. Since we want the probability that the sample mean lifespan is greater than 62 days, we need to find the area to the right of the z-score:

P(X̄ > 62) = 1 - P(X̄ ≤ 62)
P(X̄ > 62) = 1 - 0.9996
P(X̄ > 62) ≈ 0.0004

So, the probability that the sample mean lifespan is greater than 62 days is approximately 0.0004 or 0.04%.
